course.subject: MECH
course.name: Solid Mechanics I
course.description: Forces, moments, equilibrium; principles of virtual work; analysis of structural members under axial load, torsion and bending; shear force and bending moment diagrams; statically indeterminate trusses; buckling and structural stability.

reviews.author: Ho Ka Ying
reviews.title: Huge gap from MECH 2020
reviews.comment_content:
Stress, shear stress, tension, moment, bending, twisting etc

Huge gap from MECH 2020!! (2020 is too easy perhaps)

There are lots of equations (It's better, but also hard, to understand the derivation of equations). And the harder part is to use them.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear and good!!! Prof Ye is patient and willing to answer questions. Even in Zoom, the lessons are good.
reviews.comment_grading: Good! The exam is similar to the past paper, which they will provide for us.
reviews.comment_workload:
Mid term, final, assignments.

Require some efforts in doing HW (difficult), and understanding equations bu viewing examples.

reviews.author: bupa
reviews.comment_content:
每個topic都只係教淺嗰啲part, 如果睇返書會見到啲advanced嘅唔會考
notes有少少跳topic 有啲易撈亂啲equation 因為會用類似symbol
成個course嘅大佬係要prove啲deflection equation再用superposition計 solution會好長好煩
reviews.comment_teaching:
mainland prof 少少口音不過流利
上堂會一齊做example
傾計太大聲會鬧

ta全部都係mainland所以唔使期望太多
reviews.comment_grading:
mean估計B+
10% quiz
10% assignment
30% midterm
50% final (大槪)
midterm易啲但問題用字同notes會唔同 mean六七成
final無分睇
reviews.comment_workload:
1~2個禮拜一份assignment 4-5條long q 照出書可以抄source
上堂會有突擊quiz 好簡單 eg寫prof名

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Stress and Strain (Literally)
reviews.comment_content:
Despite increased difficulty, MECH2040 is still an extension of MECH2020 that took account on deformation based on the mechanics you've studied in your last semester:

1. Concept of Stress
2. Stress and Strain under Axial Loading
3. Torsion
4. Pure bending
5. Transverse loading
-------Midterm-------
6. Transformation of Stress/Mohr Circle
7. Design of Beams for Strength
8. Deflection of Beams by Integration
9. Columns and Buckling
10. Energy Method

All of them are fresh topics distinct from MECH2020 or your high school Physics concept, so skipping lectures is certainly a bad idea. Concepts and skills from MECH2020 are expected to be applied, especially methods of finding internal forces and truss analysis.

In addition, the course instructors gave us a lot of extra contents that are not taught in lectures. All of these contents should be fairly useful in your future engineering studying and experience.

One should take notice that the course is calculation extensive, so purchasing the textbook will help you in tackling assignment questions a lot, and prepares you for exams better.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In general, Professor Ye did give us a clear learning experience. As the course is calculation extensive, a number of course contents are written and explained on her screen/digital whiteboard. Her notes are mainly for reference and showing examples.

When compared to MECH2020's Professor Robin Ma, you will notice that Professor Ye's teaching included much less examples. As a result, those who're accustomed to the teaching style of Robin Ma (including me) may feel strange in her lectures. That said, as demonstrations of experiments were expected to be conducted in face-to-face lectures, such difference seems reasonable.

As for the TAs, Li Mengmeng's tutorial sessions are rather "hea". She typically only gives us 2 to 3 minutes to think about each tutorial questions, then releases the answers to us summarily. As a result her tutorials generally only last for some 30 minutes. On the other hand, both Guo Zixiao and Li Kangjie performed better in tutorial classes, with sufficient time for students to try on each questions and detailed explanation.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments (x10): 20% (Mean generally over 80%)
Midterm: 35% (MC: 32/44, LQ: 23/56; mean 29.46/44 and 23.45/56)
Final: 45% (Never released, but should be sufficiently good)

I'm not sure whether how other students finished their assignments, but the means for assignments are ridiculously high, generally over some 80%, and occasionally rising over 90%. Among all assignments, only 2 of my assignments attained full mark, and the rest of them are below the mean.

On the other hand, the exam questions aren't really hard if you can solve them one by one with calmness and confidence. While the midterm long questions looks confusing (like, what is the angular deflection of a complicated object fixed to a wall), the solution is really straightforward: that's what I found out when they released the midterm's solution.

At the end I get a surprised A- for the course, which seems that the questions I done during the study break aren't vain.
reviews.comment_workload:
An assignment was released per chapter, and we had 1 week to finish each assignment (except the one given during the midterm week). Assignment questions were taken from the textbooks, and typically went much deeper than the examples shown in classes. When combined with the workload of other classes, such arrangement is rather tight for us.

This highlights the importance of buying a course textbook for further understanding, as you can check your answers or do similar questions if you don't understand some of the concepts.

Regarding the exams, doing a lot of textbook questions and past papers can significantly help with your results. Professor Ye did provide us with last year's midterm and final, though more is better. Concepts are also important. One of the final question asked you to explain whether a beam will buckle under a sufficiently big tensile/compressive force. If you didn't go through the concept, you'll miss these easy marks.

reviews.author: Yicky
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Tao spends quite a lot of time explaining things clearly and she is willing to go over again if students are not understood. Certain non-graded chapter quiz is given for concept check.
reviews.comment_grading: grading is not bad. although the exam is quite difficult. You may expect you don't understand the long question even if you can do all the assignments. The mean is quite low for long questions but the mc mean is higher than half. Make sure you submit all your homework will be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: typical mech course. weekly homework with midterm and final. No attendance is required.

reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term, the content is not to complicated mostly about
axial stress, torsion, shear stress, pure bending with a little content from MECH2020.

After mid-term, it's getting a bit complex. It's about transvers loading, deformation due to transvers loading, column and energy method. All of those topic are close related to the content before mid-term.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For lecture, professor Tao explain every thing clearly and make sure there is no doubt before move on. I think after mid-term each lecture is important please try to attain all the class otherwise, it is difficult to understand the concept.
Both professor Tao and the TAs are willing to answer the your question and response even you approach after lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mid-term and exam consist two part, the MC questions and long questions.
MC:52% Long question:48% for both mid-term and exam.
Grading is straight forward, I guess.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignment will issue once a week. The assignment is a bit difficult. However, if you are able to solve the assignment, you might be able to solve the exam questions.
Sometimes there will be non-graded review quiz at the end of the finished chapter.

reviews.author: JCjc
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture Contents:
Chapter 1       Concept of stress
Chapter 2       Stress and strain --- axial loading
Chapter 3       Torsion
Chapter 4       Pure bending
Chapter 5       Transverse loading
Chapter 6       Transformation of stress
Chapter 7       Design of beams for strength         
Chapter 8       Deflection of beams
Chapter 9       Columns
Chapter 10     Energy methods
reviews.comment_teaching: Really bad. Her accent is hard to listen to and sleepy. That's why I didn't attend any lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
homework 20%
midterm30%
final 50%
grading is fair as long as u have study, however, it is hard for those who didn't. Attending lessons is no use in my opinion as I can't even notice what she saying.
No attendance taking at all.
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of assignments, about one per lecture. The workload is quite heavy though there are no quizzes and projects as you need to put lots of time on each homework.

reviews.author: vick
reviews.title: Dr Sun is a great prof
reviews.comment_content: Solid mechanics, a continuation from MECH 2020. Make sure you revise a bit of 2020 before 2040.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Sun is definitely the best MECH prof in UST. Do attend his lectures, and try to ask him questions after or before class. He is very approachable, and is always happy to answer questions. He is really enthusiastic about his teaching, unlike many other MECH profs who clearly dont care much about teaching.

His teaching in class is very clear and concise, and he focuses on understanding the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair and straight forward grading. Prof Sun really focuses on concepts and puts a lot of emphasis on understanding the concepts rather than having long calculations.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not too high. As long as you follow his lectures carefully, and understand the concepts, the work is manageable.

reviews.author: Fishrk
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 : Concept of stress (~1.5 weeks)
Chapter 2 : Stress and strain-axial loading   (~1.5 weeks)
Chapter 3 : Torsion (~1 week)
Chapter 4 : Pure bending (~1 week)
Chapter 5 : Transverse loading (~1 week)
Chapter 6 : Transformation of stress (~1 week)
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Sun has a soft voice. Which means you can't listen to what he is saying during the lesson easily. He has a lot of knowledge to provide. But the way he teaches is the true problem. Basically, the notes are quite useless, since it provided minimum information toward the course. You may need to consider buying the book or online self-study.
reviews.comment_grading: They have provided past papers before mid-term and exam. So it is pretty easy to have a good score.
reviews.comment_workload: About 10 homework for the whole courses. It takes a lot of time if you are not good at it. You may need to self-study a little bit in order to have the knowledge to finish it.

reviews.author: MS01
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1        Concept of stress
Chapter 2        Stress and strain
Chapter 3        Torsion
Chapter 4        Pure bending
Chapter 5        Transverse loading
-------------Mid term Exam-----------------------
Chapter 6          Transformation of stress
Chapter 7          Design of beams for strength     
Chapter 8          Deflection of beams
Chapter 9          Columns
Chapter 10        Energy methods

Final Exam only covered Chapter 6 to 10.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Sun taught his subject with heart and he used the projector to explain things in details by drawing different figures. He has more than twenty years of experience teaching this subject and knows what are the common mistakes done by students.

However, lecture notes are quite brief and outdated. Therefore, you really had to take notes in order to know what was happening.

LECTURE VIDEOS WILL UPDATED REGULARLY!!!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 20%
Midterm Exam: 30% (mean: ~55; SD: ~16)
Final Exam: 50%
-------------------------------------
Midterm exam below mean 0.5 SD, 93% in homework, unknown result of the final exam. Ended up a B-
reviews.comment_workload: Homework released nearly every week. But you can find the answer in the Internet.

reviews.author: anis
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 : Concept of stress (~1.5 weeks)
Chapter 2 : Stress and strain-axial loading   (~1.5 weeks)
Chapter 3 : Torsion (~1 week)
Chapter 4 : Pure bending (~1 week)
Chapter 5 : Transverse loading (~1 week)
Chapter 6 : Transformation of stress (~1 week)
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Sun uses a clear and efficient method to teach. He has more than twenty years of experience teaching Solid Mechanics and knows the material to the last detail. He is always eager to answer the students' questions and always wants to make sure the answer is clear.
reviews.comment_grading: I had around 50% in both Mid Term and Final Exam. Almost always full mark in homeworks. Ended up having a C.

reviews.author: potat0
reviews.comment_content:
The content of the course is not hard, and covers everything from the basics.
- Axial and shear loading
- Bending
- Torsion
- Shear and bending diagrams
- Compression and columns
- etc.
Overlaps with MECH3520 Design II
No textbook, no attendance, homework once a week, nothing much happens during tutorials. VIDEO LECTURE UPLOADED.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not the best English around but he explains very well the reason behind the relations in the notes. he annotates his notes by hand during lecture and doesn't upload the completed version afterwards (old school prof- but notes are complete enough even without his annotations, so it's OK to miss classes). HE gets very passionate about his subject which is quite rare. Very nice prof, he'll do his best to explain if you don't understand something
reviews.comment_grading: The content is fairly easy, therefore, according to the UST theorem of grading, the curve is a bit nasty. But not that much, compared to business courses, the curve is more lenient.
reviews.comment_workload: Just homework once a week to which you can find the answers online in less than 5 min. Non cumulative final (only 3 chapters covered in the final....) and just easy material. No textbook to read and the notes are really short.
